And since I was trained by the greatest textual scholar who ever lived, the greatest bibliographical theorist who ever lived, Fredson Bowers at the University of Virginia, I was trained in the methods of recovering the author's intention, the way to edit what was called in those days a definitive edition.
And so therefore, I have done definitive editions of Gatsby,
Tender and The Last Tycoon, for which I recovered Fitzgerald's title, The Love of the Last Tycoon.
That was Fitzgerald's title.
It was published as The Last Tycoon because Edmund Wilson, who did the salvage job, didn't like Love of the Last Tycoon, and he called it The Last Tycoon.
But I have done what used to be called definitive editions, which has become a junk word.
That word definitive.
has become cheapened and meaningless.
So I prefer to use the term critical edition.

A critical edition is an edition based on all of the drafts, pre-publication material, as well as the alterations and revisions the author may have made in the book post-publication, when the book was reset.
And impossible to do it.
without the material in this room.
If there was a reason for building the collection, it was so I could do critical editions of F. Scott Fitzgerald.

causes me to grieve.
I don't think Hemingway is in good hands.

Faulkner certainly deserves it.
In 20th century writers, Dos Passos, probably.
Probably USA requires editing.
Editing in the sense of recovering and preserving Das Paso's intentions.
You were involved some years back on recovering what you called lost.
For seven years, I was director of the Center for Editions of American Authors.
which was funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
And we did Hawthorne, and we did Melville, and we did Emerson, and we did Thoreau, and we did Whitman, the American classics.
Oh, sure.
So then we have the Library of America trying to do that, doing that.
Well, I have grave reservations about the Library of America.
I've never seen a nonprofit organization so profitable.
But the Center of Editions of American Authors, or CAA, as it was called, had 144 definitive editions or critical editions completed at the time I resigned.
But was it largely 19th-century type of authors that you mentioned?

Sure.

Indeed, and undoubtedly will drive you crazy, not only can.

He was not the uneducated,
man that the rumors would have.
Sure, he was probably the worst student Princeton ever had.
Doesn't signify anything.
Fitzgerald knew that there was nothing in the chemistry classrooms and the math classrooms at Princeton he needed, that he could possibly use.
So he flunked out.
because he neglected the required courses, and he wrote for every publication at Princeton, with the exception of the Daily Princetonian.
But he wrote three Triangle Club shows, wrote his first Triangle Club show as a freshman.
Wow.
He wrote whole issues of the Princeton Tiger overnight.
He wrote serious short stories
and a great deal of poetry.
When he was at Princeton, he wasn't sure whether he wanted to be a novelist or a poet for the Nassau Literary Magazine.
And this section here has all of his Princetoniana, some of it very rare.
In addition, it has the
second of the only known two complete runs of his St.
Paul Academy, which was a day school.
He attended in St.
Paul between 1910 and 1912.
This volume, which unfortunately was rebound when I got it, and for some reason, the issues weren't bound in chronological order.
Nonetheless, this volume is a complete set
of the issues of the St.
Paul Academy now and then, 1910, 1912, which has all of Fitzgerald's earliest publications.
That's what matters.
And there are two sets in the world, reputedly one at the St.
Paul Academy, which I've never seen, and this one.
There you go.
Pretty good, and in remarkably great shape.

Are you able to assess the impact that Fitzgerald had on, you know, the readership, his times, and whether or not you feel, and I don't want to really mean to go off on a wild tangent, but I am kind of interested in your thoughts on, is it possible for a novelist, a fiction writer today, to have the kind of impact that people, that writers such as Fitzgerald might have had?
I think not because of electronic.
So you are fearful then that this is... Publication.
Fitzgerald was a words-on-paper writer.
Fitzgerald wrote at the time when reading was not just a habit of certain people, but when everybody read.
It was a time when there were
scores of mass-circulation magazines, and they all had fiction.
It was a time when there wereevery American city had multiple newspapers.
People read the morning paper, people read the afternoon paper.
I did, too.
My father brought home five newspapers a day.
I think I got most of my education from William Randolph Hearst in my boyhood.
Fitzgerald and Hemingway and Faulkner, all of the geniuses of the 1920s into the 1930s, were writing for an audience of hungry readers, people who read spontaneously
for pleasure, for enjoyment.
And I don't think any reader, after, oh, the 60s, which have a lot to answer for, approaches, approached then, approaches now.
the reading experience, the little black marks on the pieces of paper, the way Fitzgerald's readers and Hemingway's readers and Faulkner's readers responded to the experience of reading literature.
And then the computers came along and turned everyone's brains to mush.
